Top 5 Banned Movies

By James Bithell

<em>The Human Centipede II</em> isn't the first movie to feel the wrath of the BBFC - here are five classics that were once on the UK banned list

The Human Centipede II

This month the BBFC refused to certify a film for commercial release in the UK. Adrian Choa looks at what the fuss is all about

Green Lantern

<em>Green Lantern</em> is one of those films that gets everything right apart from acting and plot. It's a terrible movie, shrouded in great cinematography, spellbinding visual effects and a gloriously dramatic score

Senna

To refer to Asif Kapadia as the director of <em>Senna</em> is in many ways misleading. Leaving behind him a wealth of archive footage Senna can be said to have narrated his own life, and so Kapadia has not had to shoot a single frame of this movie

X-Men: First Class

Abandon all your preconceptions about comic book films at the door - you won't be needing them

There's nothing beautiful left to see

Guillem Morales talks to Gareth Davies about his latest film <em>Julia's Eyes</em> (Thumbnail credit Belen Rueda in Julia's Eyes)

Top 5 Terence Malick Movies

By James Bithell

Having just won the Palme d'Or at Cannes, here's our pick of this 67-year-old American filmmaker's best offerings to the silver screen

Movie piracy: on stranger tides

The movie industry isn't expendable, argues <em>Christopher Fraser</em>, but neither are those targeted for illegal movie downloads

The Hangover Part II

<em>The Hangover: Part II</em> is very similar to its predecessor. It starts half-way through the story with the same "we messed up" phone call before skipping to One Week Earlier

Pirates of the Caribbean 4

Just when you thought a storyline had finally been milked of all it's worth, Disney reminds us all yet again that if it makes money, it can also make as many sequels as it wants

Win Win

Chubby, balding, and self-consciously geeky. Paul Giamatti may not be the most glamorous of film-stars; but in recent years he has proven himself to be one of the most accomplished.

Cannes 2011: Sun Sea and ...Anti-Semitism?

Winner of the coveted Palme d'Or this year is Terrence Malick's long-awaited <em>The Tree of Life</em>, a movie which has garnered critical acclaim since its screening six days ago at the festival.

13 Assassins

<em>13 Assassins</em> sees the notorious Takashi Miike moving in new directions, and embracing a form which seems in some ways more mature than the twisted yakuza dramas he is most well-known for.

Priest 3D

<em>Priest 3D</em> is a disappointment of a film, attempting to recreate the atmospheric horror of <em>Underworld</em>, but managing only to conjure images of a grittier <em>Twilight</em>.

Pina

"What are we longing for? Where does all this yearning come from?" Wim Wenders' 3D cinematic tribute to legendary pioneer of modern dance, Pina Bausch, spends an engaging hour-an-a-half asking us, without words, just that

Taxi Driver: 35 Years of Travis Bickle

It's 35 Years since Martin Scorsese's <em>Taxi Driver</em> first hit the big screens and, to celebrate its re-release, Michael Middleton looks at its disturbing protagonist Travis Bickle: one of Robert De Niro's finest creations and possibly Cinema's greatest anti-hero.

Attack the Block

While its premise objectively seems to be clever, funny, scary and entertaining, <em>Attack the Block</em> sadly only manages to tick the last box

Unlawful Killing: The Film the British Won't Get To See

Aside from the speculation surrounding the films in the running to win the Palme d'Or, a documentary from British film maker Keith Allen, entitled <em>Unlawful Killing</em> has certainly ruffled a few feathers.

16mm: An Economy of Negatives?

As 16mm film is discontinued in the UK <em>Gareth Davies</em> looks at the fragile future of celluloid film, in an industry increasingly dominated by digital technologies

Top 5 Samurai Movies

To celebrate the release of cult director Takashi Miike's new movie <em>13 Assassins</em>, <em>Nouse</em> look at the five greatest samurai films ever made

Farewell

Loosely based on the actions of KGB official Vladimir Vetrov, <em>Farewell</em> has the potential to shed light on this little-known piece of Cold War history

Thor

Trying to incorporate 50 years of comic book history into a two hour film is no mean feat, even for Kenneth Branagh, who no doubt had a difficult task on his hands with <em>Thor</em> in attempting to please a long-standing fan-base whilst putting his own stamp on the character

Cannes 2011: The Contenders

Today sees the launch of the 64th annual Cannes Film Festival. The festival, which runs for an eleven day period (from 11-22 May) opened with Woody Allen's <em>Midnight In Paris</em>.

Fast and Furious 5 (Fast Five)

Vin Diesel and Paul Walker return as the dynamic duo, with brain, brawn and pretty boy looks.

Citizen Kane: 70 Years On

Last week saw the seventy-year anniversary of the release of <em>Citizen Kane</em>. Gareth Davies looks at some of the formal aspects of the film which have helped seal its status as a work of cinematic genius.

The Extraordinary Adventures of Adele Blanc-Sec

One might be forgiven for mistaking this for a Jean-Pierre Jeunet movie. Its very fabric oozes his trademark: a dense and crisp contrast which, rendered in a nostalgia-inducing sepia-tone, gives his movies a particularly gallic aesthetic.

Top 5 Silent Movies

To celebrate the re-release of the classic silent movie <em>Battleship Potemkin</em>, Gareth Davies looks at five silent movies which are essential viewing for cinephiles

Arthur

Is Russell Brand an actor? It's that question that lies at the centre of this film

Your Highness

This is a stupid, stupid film with next to no depth that redefines the word "gratuitous" for a new generation. It's brilliant

Scre4m

Almost inevitably, more than one ditsy teenager answers the door seconds after having hung up on an evil-sounding caller who's just told them "my face will be the last sight you see"
